sub_topic: Calculation of the mass of a substance deposited or dissolved during an electrochemical reaction
message_1: What mass of silver (Ag) will be deposited on the cathode in the electrolysis of AgNO3 solution with a current of 2.5 A flowing for 45 minutes? (Assuming 100% current efficiency)
message_2:
To determine the mass of silver deposited on the cathode, we can use Faraday's laws of electrolysis. First, we need to find the charge (Q) passed through the solution:

Q = current (I) × time (t)
where I = 2.5 A and t = 45 minutes = 2700 seconds

Q = 2.5 A × 2700 s = 6750 C (coulombs)

Next, we need to find the number of moles of electrons (n) transferred:

n = Q / (F × z)
where F = Faraday's constant (96485 C/mol) and z = number of electrons transferred per mole of silver (1 for Ag+)

n = 6750 C / (96485 C/mol × 1) = 0.0699 mol

Now, we can find the mass of silver deposited:

mass = n × molar mass of silver (Ag)
where molar mass of Ag = 107.87 g/mol

mass = 0.0699 mol × 107.87 g/mol = 7.54 g

So, 7.54 grams of silver will be deposited on the cathode during the electrolysis of AgNO3 solution with a current of 2.5 A flowing for 45 minutes, assuming 100% current efficiency.
